Award.AwardTitle: NRI/Collaborative Research: Improving the Safety and Agility of Robotic Flight with Bat-Inspired Flexible-Winged Robots

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bat flight, perhaps the most advanced and efficient form of animal flight, has long been a source of inspiration for roboticists and biologists alike. This National Robotics Initiative (NRI) collaborative research award supports research aimed at understanding and reproducing the unparalleled agility and resilience of bat flight. Biological studies of bats (their structure, muscle movement, and flight dynamics) will drive the engineering development of mathematical models of robotic flight and the eventual design and implementation of a prototype 30-80cm bat-like robot. The physical flight capabilities of the robot will be augmented with perception and reasoning abilities, with the aim of providing support for construction site activities such as site monitoring, inspection, and general surveillance of the work site to provide image data to enhance situational awareness of human workers. The research involves several disciplines, including biology, aerodynamics, robotics, control systems engineering, and construction engineering.

Aerial robots have nowhere near the agility and efficiency of animal flight, especially in complex, constrained environments. This is not surprising since even the simplest winged robots have complex flight dynamics that pose significant challenges for modeling, design, and control. In the case of bat-inspired robots, these difficulties are exacerbated by the use of under-actuated mechanisms driving wings constructed from flexible membranes. This project will combine biological and engineering research to address these problems. Biological research on the kinematics of bats and their flight will provide a basis for mechanical designs. To control the robot, agile motion planning and flight control algorithms will employ motion primitives that are derived from biological investigation of the dynamics of bat flight. Conversely, models obtained from biological studies will be validated by experimental investigations using the prototype robot, enabling iterative refinement of reduced-order models and control algorithms. Ultimately, the robots will be equipped with sensing systems and planning algorithms, to facilitate localization, mapping, inspection and surveillance at construction sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this award, we measured, described, modeled and emulated the dynamics of bats during flight, and used new insights from animal flight to enhance development of advanced bio-inspired aerodynamic designs for small-scale flight vehicles.   

We described the landing characteristics of multiple, diverse bat species, identified three distinct landing styles that we term two-, three- and four-point landings, based on the number of limb contact points a bat uses as it maneuvers from forward flight to its roosting posture. We also discovered that a specialized bat that has distinctive adhesive discs on its wrists and ankles has evolved a completely unique mode of landing along with its specialized anatomy and use of large, furled leaf roosts.  

We detailed the manner in which bats recover when the air in which they fly is disturbed, by applying an intense gust of air that pushes them out of their equilibrium flight behavior.  We found that bats usually regain stable, symmetrical forward flight after these perturbations ("aerial stumbles") within a single wingbeat. They accomplish recovery by combining inertia and aerodynamic forces. They achieve inertial torques by adjusting the posture of their wings (limbs) to generate body rotations, much as a gymnast would do.

We have used the detailed measurements we made from these behaviors to help create a detailed dynamical model of bats and their highly articulated wings. Different versions of the model have various levels of sophistication corresponding to the precision with which they capture motion detail; models can simulate from only six to up to fifty-four degrees of freedom of movement, and can include or exclude aerodynamic forces. Using these models, we are able to reproduce landing and falling dynamics of bats, and help explain how bats can cope with the disruptions imposed by gusts so rapidly.  We also used these models to examine the dynamics of hovering in insects, birds and bats in detail. This approach explains why larger animals, such as bats, must incorporate wing folding during their hovering maneuvers, but insects and hummingbirds do not.

We developed and tested a bio-inspired drone based on principles observed in animal flight, in this case drawing on understanding of how insects fly.  This vehicle has a unique separated flow wing that is robust to atmospheric disturbances and offers the potential to greatly increase the flight time of very small scale (<100g) flight vehicles.

Lastly, we have built and tested an insect-inspired flapping wing in rotation is controlled by a torsional hinge; this is based on the morphology of the wings of small insects.  We used scaling analysis to explain the aerodynamic performance of this wing, then tested this theoretical approach with direct experiments. 

Our program has successfully trained several postdoctoral fellows, and graduate and undergraduate students. They have received training interdisciplinary training in quantitative, physical, and biological sciences in the course of carrying out hands-on, cutting edge research. They have participated in all aspects of the research enterprise, including gaining relevant background, research planning, experimental design, data analysis and presentation, scientific writing, and public presentations. We have offered training for communicating about scientific subjects to expert researchers as well as for more general audiences of a variety of backgrounds and ages. Our postdocs have successfully obtained positions in academia, business, and industry. Graduate students who have participated in this program have received or are completing degrees, and some currently build on the work begun in this program as postdoctoral trainees. Our undergraduate researchers have used their experiences in our lab in a broad variety of ways, including as a stepping stone to admission to Ph.D. programs and medical schools, as well as pursuing careers within and outside of STEM fields.

We have conveyed our research findings with many scientific audiences through scholarly publications and attendance at professional conferences. We have shared aspects of our research with many general audiences. These include coverage such as NPR’s Science Friday Macroscope videoblog, the New York Times Science Takes features, public television documentaries and other high-visibility science journalism venues, as well as participation in K-12 education in local schools, annual school outreach in Orange Walk, Belize, the national Skype-a-Scientist program, and outreach to the Rhode Island Department of Corrections.
